title: Cancer Deaths 2013-2023 Multnomah County
text:
Cancer remains one of the leading causes of death in the United States, with significant disparities in outcomes across racial and ethnic groups (CDC 2023). While overall cancer mortality has started to decline since the turn of the century, these improvements have not been equitably distributed.

For example, Black Americans experience the highest cancer death rates, particularly for prostate and colorectal cancers (CDC 2025). Additionally, while Native American and Alaska Native populations have seen increasing mortality rates for some cancer types—particularly lung, colo-rectal, liver, stomach, and kidney cancers (Jack and Mitchell 2023).
These disparities are shaped by a structural racism and a multitude of environmental disparities, including unequal access to timely care and differences in insurance coverage (Jack and Mitchell).
Despite growing awareness of the relationship between cancer deaths and race, the public health literature remains limited in its exploration of how these disparities vary at local levels. This study aims to examine the relationship between race/ethnicity and cancer-related deaths in the Multnomah county, with the goal of identifying persistent gaps in outcomes.

title: Abstract
text:
Abstract
This project analyzes cancer mortality data from Multnomah County, focusing on how the top three causes of cancer-related deaths have varied across racial and ethnic groups over the past ten years. Race and ethnicity were selected as key variables due to their deep connections with structural factors such as geographic location, access to care, and economic status. Historically, communities of color in Multnomah County have been disproportionately impacted by health inequities stemming from systemic discrimination. By centering these populations in our analysis, this research aims to bring visibility to patterns of disparity that are often underrepresented in public health data. The findings from this study are intended to support the Multnomah County Health Department in developing more informed, equitable, and community-responsive health policies moving forward.

title: Cancer Deaths 2013-2023 Multnomah County
text:
Cancer remains one of the leading causes of death in the United States, with significant disparities in outcomes across racial and ethnic groups (CDC 2023). While overall cancer mortality has started to decline since the turn of the century, these improvements have not been equitably distributed.

For example, Black Americans experience the highest cancer death rates, particularly for prostate and colorectal cancers (CDC 2025). Additionally, while Native American and Alaska Native populations have seen increasing mortality rates for some cancer types—particularly lung, colo-rectal, liver, stomach, and kidney cancers (Jack and Mitchell 2023).
These disparities are shaped by a structural racism and a multitude of environmental disparities, including unequal access to timely care and differences in insurance coverage (Jack and Mitchell).
Despite growing awareness of the relationship between cancer deaths and race, the public health literature remains limited in its exploration of how these disparities vary at local levels. This study aims to examine the relationship between race/ethnicity and cancer-related deaths in the Multnomah county, with the goal of identifying persistent gaps in outcomes.
crumbs.title: Aim of Research
crumbs.text: The aim of this research is to investigate how the top three types of cancer-related deaths have varied across different racial and ethnic groups in Multnomah County over the past ten years. By identifying patterns and disparities in cancer mortality, this study seeks to understand how structural inequalities, such as access to healthcare and historical discrimination, may contribute to unequal health outcomes. We have centered our core variables to race and ethnicity to be able to move beyond surface-level data and instead focus on the lived experiences of communities that have often been excluded from dominant health narratives. Ultimately, this research aims to inform more inclusive public health strategies and contribute to ongoing efforts toward health equity and justice.
